div.p: REBELLION Rebellio, among the Romans, was where thoſe who had been formerly overcome in bat-tle, and yielded to their fubjection, made a ſecond rς-ſiſtance ; but with us it is generally uſed ſor the taking

up of arms traiterouſly againft the king, whether by na-tural ſubjects, or others when once ſubdued ; and the word rebel is ſometimes applied to him who wilfully breaks a law ; alfo to a villein diſobeying his lord.

There is a difference between enemies and rebels. Enemies are thoſe who are out of the king’s allegiance: therefore fubjects of the king, either in open war, or rebellion, are not the king’s enemies, but traitors. And David Prince of λVales, who levied war againft Edw. I. becauſe he was within the allegiance of the king, had ſentence pronounced againft him as a traitor and rebel. Private perſons may arm themſelves to ſuppreſs rebels, enemies, &c.
